questions.text: In a small coastal town in Kerala, a sudden surge of gastroenteritis cases is reported within two days after a community seafood feast. Health officials suspect the seafood feast as the source of the epidemic. Which of the following statements is true regarding this type of single exposure point source epidemic? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Explosive in nature

 

Single exposure or ‘Point source’ epidemics characteristics:

 

  • ‘Sharp rise and sharp fall’ in no. of cases i.e., single wave 
  • ‘Clustering of cases’ in a narrow interval of time
  • All ‘cases develop within one incubation period’ of the disease.
  • Examples: Food poisoning, Measles, Chicken pox, Cholera, BHOPAL GAS TRAGEDY

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. With more than 1 incubation period: Incorrect as single exposure epidemics are confined to one incubation period.

 

Option C. With multiple peaks: Incorrect as single exposure epidemics typically have a single peak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single exposure point source epidemics are explosive in nature with a rapid increase and decline in cases, confined to one incubation period.

questions.text: Under which health program, the School Health was combined in the year 2018? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ayushman Bharat program

 

Explanation:

 

In 2018, the School Health program was integrated under the Ayushman Bharat program. This integration involved the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the Ministry of Human Resource Development. Here, School teachers to be made the Health & Wellness ambassadors

 

The program focuses on various health initiatives for school children are –

 

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation,
  • Deworming with albendazole tablets,
  • Distribution of sanitary napkins to adolescent girls,
  • Age-appropriate vaccination,
  • Maintenance of electronic health records, and
  • Teaching first aid.
  • Additionally, the program is part of the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karikram (RBSK), targeting the screening of 30 disorders in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia Mukt Bharat program: This program aims to reduce anemia across the population, particularly among women and children, but it is not the program under which the School Health program was integrated in 2018.

 

Option C. Swachh Bharat Mission: This initiative focuses on cleanliness and sanitation across India but is not related to the School Health program integration.

 

Option D. Poshan Abhiyan: This mission targets improving nutritional outcomes for children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers but does not encompass the School Health program's integration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 2018, the School Health program was integrated into the Ayushman Bharat program, involving health and wellness initiatives for school children.

questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1000

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated using the formula:

In this case:

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.text: The term "paradoxical carrier" is defined as: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

 

A paradoxical carrier is defined as a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, yet does not exhibit any signs or symptoms of the disease. This situation is paradoxical because the pathogen is typically transmitted directly from an infected patient to a new host, but in this case, it has been passed from one asymptomatic carrier to another. This type of carrier plays a significant role in the epidemiology of certain infectious diseases by perpetuating the transmission cycle without showing clinical symptoms themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period:  This describes an incubatory carrier, who sheds infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. This is different from a paradoxical carrier, as it involves shedding pathogens before symptoms appear.

 

Option C. A person who acquired pathogen from patient:  This does not describe a paradoxical carrier. It refers to a typical transmission scenario where a pathogen is acquired directly from an infected patient, rather than another asymptomatic carrier.

 

Option D. A patient who became a carrier:  This refers to a convalescent carrier or a chronic carrier. A convalescent carrier is someone who continues to shed the disease agent during the recovery period, while a chronic carrier harbors the pathogen long-term. Neither term is synonymous with a paradoxical carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
  • Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.
  • Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.
  • Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.

questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lab coat

 

A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

 

While lab coats are worn in laboratory settings to protect clothing and skin from spills and splashes, they are not classified as PPE. PPE refers to more specialized equipment designed to provide a barrier against specific hazards.

 

Other 3 options are considered as PPE

 

Educational Objective:

 

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

 

  • Gloves - protect hands.
  • Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing.
  • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • Goggles - protect eyes.
  • Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.

questions.text: In the accompanying illustration, a treatment approach for a patient with lymphatic filariasis is depicted. Which type of preventive method is illustrated in this scenario? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disability limitation

 

  • The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection.
  • Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

 

Option C. Primary prevention: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Health promotion: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.

questions.text: A female 29 years old is on a Combined OCP regimen for contraception. All of the following cancers may be seen in her except (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ovarian cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. OCPs are protective against benign breast diseases, benign & malignant ovarian diseases but have been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and cervical cancer. Thus, ovarian cancer is the correct answer, as it is the exception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast cancer: Combined OCPs may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: There is evidence that long-term use of combined OCPs can increase the risk of cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills reduce the risk of ovarian cancer while potentially increasing the risk of breast and cervical cancers.

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4-8%

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is higher than in non-consanguineous marriages. The risk depends on several factors, such as the prevalence of genetic diseases in the population, the degree of consanguinity, and the genetic makeup of the couple.

 

The estimated risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population's risk of around 2-4%. However, the risk can vary widely depending on the specific genetic diseases and the population's prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is estimated to be around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population risk of approximately 2-4%.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible
Clear eyes with a sterile swab
Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Bath to newborn with warm water

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended as it can cause rapid heat loss and hypothermia in the infant. Instead, after delivery, the newborn should be wiped clean with a sterile cloth and wrapped warmly without giving a bath. The bath can be delayed until at least 24 hours after birth or later when the baby’s body temperature has stabilized, especially in settings without advanced care facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start breastfeeding as soon as possible: It is recommended to initiate breastfeeding immediately after birth, ideally within the first hour for vaginal deliveries and within 4 hours for cesarean sections. Early breastfeeding provides the newborn with essential nutrients and antibodies and helps stimulate milk production.

 

Option B. Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the eyes of a newborn with a sterile swab is correct. If needed, antiseptic solutions like 1% silver nitrate or 1% tetracycline ointment can be used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum, an eye infection that can occur in newborns.

 

Option D. Cover baby’s head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is essential to prevent heat loss. Newborns lose up to 75% of their body heat through the head, making it crucial to keep the baby warm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: A child presented to PHC OPD with skin rash and depigmented hair. He gives a history of swollen/bleeding gums. X-ray picture is shown below. He is suffering from: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Copper deficiency


The clinical presentation of the child, including skin rash, depigmented hair, swollen/bleeding gums, and the X-ray findings, suggests a deficiency that closely mimics scurvy (vitamin C deficiency). However, in this question, the exact cause is copper deficiency, which shares similar symptoms and radiological appearances with scurvy. Copper plays a crucial role in various metabolic pathways, including those influenced by vitamin C, such as collagen synthesis and connective tissue health. Copper deficiency is known as pseudoscurvy because it presents with nearly identical clinical and radiological features as vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zinc deficiency: Zinc deficiency typically presents with symptoms such as delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, and dermatitis, particularly around orifices. It does not cause the specific combination of bleeding gums, depigmented hair, and the radiological changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency usually presents with symptoms related to anemia, such as fatigue, pallor, and pica. While it can cause brittle nails and hair changes, it does not present with bleeding gums and specific X-ray findings as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency: Selenium deficiency primarily affects the heart and muscles, leading to conditions like Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and muscle weakness. It does not cause the bleeding gums, depigmented hair, or the bone abnormalities observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Copper deficiency can mimic vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) in its clinical and radiological presentation, a condition often referred to as pseudoscurvy.

questions.text: As the in-charge epidemiologist of an urban CHC, you've been reviewing the weekly infectious disease reports. In a particular community under your jurisdiction, you observe that dengue case counts typically range from 40 to 50 cases every week. During your current weekly review, you note there are 48 reported cases of dengue. Based on this data and your understanding of epidemiological terminology, how would you classify this week's situation with respect to dengue? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Endemic 

 

  • The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease.

 

Endemic

 

  • Endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
    • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
    • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic: Incorrect because an epidemic refers to an increase in the number of cases of a disease beyond what is normally expected in that population in that area. The current case count does not exceed the usual range.

 

Option C. Sporadic: Incorrect because sporadic refers to a disease that occurs infrequently and irregularly; here, the cases are neither infrequent nor irregular.

 

Option D. Outbreak: Similar to an epidemic, an outbreak implies a greater-than-anticipated increase in the number of cases within a small, localized area over a short period. Again, since the case count is within normal expectations, this term does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) History of diet

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Bowing of legs with bleeding gums is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

Explanation:

 

Bowing of legs can be mistakenly attributed to vitamin D deficiency, which typically causes rickets in children.

 

However, the presence of bleeding gums points specifically to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Vitamin C is crucial for collagen synthesis and other structural aspects of bone formation. This deficiency, known as scurvy, involves various skeletal changes including defective osteoid matrix formation and osteolysis, beyond just the commonly noted bleeding gums. The combined symptoms of bowing of legs and bleeding gums can indeed suggest a scenario where vitamin C deficiency plays a contributory role alongside other deficiencies like vitamin D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and epithelial tissues, not typically associated with bleeding gums or significant skeletal changes like bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Incorrect as Vitamin E deficiency generally leads to neurological problems and muscle weakness, not directly linked with bleeding gums or bone deformities.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Incorrect because while Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, its deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of legs; it would rather lead to bleeding issues without the skeletal deformities noted here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin C deficiency can cause bleeding gums and is associated with significant bone structure changes, leading to conditions like scurvy that may present with skeletal deformities such as bowing of legs.

choices.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice a week
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a week
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a month

questions.text: What dose of iron and folic acid should an anemic pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, which aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India by 3 percentage points every year, the "6 by 6 by 6" strategy is used. This strategy targets 6 beneficiaries, includes 6 interventions, and involves 6 institutional mechanisms.

 

 

One of the interventions is iron and folic acid supplementation.

 

Anemic pregnant women in their second trimester should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days, as per the guidelines of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program.

 

For pregnant women, the recommended dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy. This is provided in the form of red-colored tablets. The same dose is also given to lactating mothers for 180 days post-delivery.

 

If the woman does not respond to this dosage or is anemic, then other forms of iron supplementation, such as ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose, may be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing demographic patterns in a tribal region of Jharkhand, India. The community has high birth and death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence. In which stage of the demographic transition model is the birth rate typically the highest?  (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stage 1

 

The highest birth rate is observed in Stage 1 of the demographic cycle, characterized by both high birth and high death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence.

 

Five stages of the demographic cycle: -

 

Stage 1: (High Stationary): High Birth Rate & High Death Rate

 

Stage 2: (Early Expanding): Birth Rate Unchanged & Death Rate Decrease

 

Stage3: (Late Expanding): Birth Rate: Decreases & Death Rate: Decreases

 

Stage 4: (Late Stationary): BR: Low & DR: Low

 

Stage 5: (Declining): BR < DR/Population Decreases

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Five stages of demographic cycle

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Attributable risk

 

The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk. Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Relative risk: Is a measure of the strength of association between exposure and disease, and it compares the risk of disease in exposed individuals to the risk in non-exposed individuals.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk: Is a measure of the Incidence of the disease that is likely to be reduced if the risk factor is modified/eliminated.

 

 

Option D. Odds ratio: Is a measure of the odds of exposure among cases compared to the odds of exposure among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: As per the new guidelines of MTP Act, Medical termination of pregnancy can be done after 24 weeks for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foetus malformation

 

Explanation:

 

According to the new guidelines of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, as amended in 2021, medical termination of pregnancy is permitted in India up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Beyond 24 weeks, MTP is permissible in cases where there are documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations. In such cases, the opinion of the state medical board is required to proceed with the termination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rape: This option is incorrect because, while rape or sexual assault is one of the indications for MTP up to 24 weeks, it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Option B. Contraceptive failure: This option is incorrect because contraceptive failure is a social indication for MTP up to 24 weeks, but it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Option D. Insanity: This option is incorrect as it is not mentioned as an indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per the new guidelines of the MTP Act in India, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed beyond 24 weeks of gestation only in cases of documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations, and the opinion of the state medical board is required.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of bitot's spot is more than: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.8%

 

Explanation:

 

One of the criteria for considering xerophthalmia as a public health problem is if the prevalence of bitot's spots (a sign of vitamin A deficiency) is more than 0.5% in the population. The specifically asks about the prevalence of bitot's spots, and the option closest to 0.5% is 0.8%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevalence criteria for determining the Xerophthalmia problem in a community: (Preschool children 6 months- 6 years).

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sapna, Leprosy


The girl in the image is named Sapna, and she is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program. Sapna is an emblematic figure used to raise awareness about leprosy prevention and control through information, education, and communication (IEC) strategies. She symbolizes the message that leprosy is completely curable. Sapna herself is portrayed as a former leprosy patient who has been fully cured, aiming to reduce stigma and educate the public about the disease's curability.

 

National Leprosy Mission Trust of India is the agency who came out with the concept of the girl Sapna for Leprosy Awareness Efforts Generation.

 

Educational Objective:


Sapna is a character created to promote leprosy awareness and emphasize that leprosy is a 100% curable disease.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not result in water hardness? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Calcium carbonate

 

Hardness of water is caused by the presence of dissolved minerals, particularly calcium and magnesium ions. These minerals can come from various sources, such as natural deposits in soil and rocks, or from industrial and domestic activities.

 

There are two types of hardness of water:

 

Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.

 

Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’
  • Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3)
  • 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water
  • Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate)
  • Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates
  • Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates
  • Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man from a rural area of Bihar presents to the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital in Patna. He has been experiencing fever for the past week, associated with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and palpable lymphadenopathy. Despite being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antimalarial agents by a local practitioner, there's been no significant relief. Blood investigations for typhoid (Widal test) are negative; however, the rk39 dipstick test is positive. Based on the clinical picture and the diagnostic findings, what would be the most appropriate drug of choice for the treatment of his condition? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Liposomal Amphotericin B

 

  • This clinical presentation strongly indicates the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The recommended course of action for this patient involves the administration of liposomal amphotericin B.

 

 

Incubation Period: 10 days to 2 years (average 1 – 4 months)

 

Serological tests:

 

  • ELISA: for diagnosis as well as epidemiological field survey
  • rk 39 dipstick test
  • Indirect Flourescent Antibody Test (IFAT)
  • Direct Agglutination Test

 

 Treatment of Leishmaniasis

 

  • Sodium stibogluconate
  • Miltefosine
  • Paramomycin
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (DOC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Fluconazole is an anti-fungal, not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

 

Option C: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA

 

Option D: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) should be treated with liposomal amphotericin B, especially when diagnosed with a positive rk39 dipstick test.

questions.text: Which influenza virus was responsible for the 2009 pandemic? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) H1N1

 

The 2009 influenza pandemic, commonly referred to as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by the H1N1 influenza A virus. This virus emerged in Mexico and quickly spread worldwide, causing widespread illness and leading to a global pandemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H5N1: Known as the "bird flu" virus.

 

  • Year: First identified in 1997 in Hong Kong.
  • Impact: Primarily affects birds but can infect humans, causing severe respiratory illness.

 

Option C. H5N7: This subtype of influenza is not known to have caused any major pandemics or widespread outbreaks in humans.

 

Option D. H3N2: This subtype of influenza A virus is known to cause seasonal flu epidemics but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic.

 

  • Year: H3N2 was involved in the 1968 influenza pandemic, known as the "Hong Kong flu."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza Pandemics

 

SWINE FLU, H1N1 → 2009, Mexico

BIRD FLU, H7N9 → 2013, China

BIRD FLU, H5N1 → 1997, Hong Kong

BIRD FLU, H10N3 → 2021, China

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

The recommended course of action for a patient with a clean-cut injury who received their last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago is to administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. This recommendation is based on the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis in wound management.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is bitten by a stray dog. She had received post-exposure prophylaxis for a monkey bite two months ago. What is the appropriate management for her current rabies exposure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Wound care + IM vaccine 0,3

 

As patient has already received post-exposure prophylaxis for monkey bite, she should receive Re-exposure prophylaxis in the form of 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 along with wound care.

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP)

 

Wound Care - Immediate care 

 

Thorough washing and flushing of the wound for approximately 15 minutes, with soap or detergent and copious amounts of water, is required; Where available, an iodine-containing, or similarly viricidal, topical preparation should be applied to the wound

 

WHO Rabies Exposure Categories

 

  • Category I: Touching or feeding animals, animal licks on intact skin (no exposure)
  • Category II: Nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding (exposure)
  • Category III: Single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membrane or broken skin with saliva from animal licks, exposures due to direct contact with bats (severe exposure)

 

PEP Recommendations

 

 

Additional Information

 

Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) Administration

 

  • There are 2 types of RIG available for passive immunisation: human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG) and equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG). Both hRIG and eRIG are equally effective and safe. But eRIG is less costly than hRIG
  • Maximum dose: 20 IU (hRIG) and 40 IU (eRIG) per kg body weight
  • Given only once, as soon as possible and not beyond Day 7 after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Infiltrate as much as possible into the wound; the remainder of the calculated dose of RIG does not need to be injected IM at a distance from the wound but can be fractionated in smaller, individual syringes to be used for other patients, aseptic retention given.
  • If RIG is not available, thorough, prompt wound washing, together with immediate administration of the first vaccine dose, followed by a complete course of rabies vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld, regardless of the availability of RIG
  • If a limited amount of RIG is available, RIG allocation should be prioritized for exposed patients based on the following criteria: 
    • Multiple bites 
    • Deep wounds
    • Bites to highly innervated parts of the body (such as head, neck and hands)
    • Severe immunodeficiency
    • Biting animal is a confirmed or probable rabies case. 
    • Bites, scratches or exposures of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For individuals with a recent history of rabies vaccination (within the past three months), re-exposure prophylaxis includes wound care and two doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of a disease with an incidence of a disease of 4 cases per 1000 individuals in the population and an average duration of 2 years? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 8/1000

 

Prevalence represents the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time. It can be calculated using the relationship between incidence (the rate of new cases) and the average duration of the disease.

 

Given that the incidence of the disease is 4 per 1000 of the population, and the average duration of the disease is 2 years, we can calculate the prevalence as follows:

 

Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 or 0.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence can be calculated using the formula:

 

Prevalence = Incidence x Duration.

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options is not recommended for use during pregnancy? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Varicella

 

The Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women because it is a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus, which can potentially cross the placenta and infect the fetus, leading to congenital infection or other complications. The primary concern is that the live virus, although weakened, may still pose a risk to the developing fetus.

 

Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy to minimize any potential risks to the fetus. Pregnant women are advised to receive inactivated vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens and are considered safer for both the mother and the unborn child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A:  The Hepatitis A vaccine is an inactivated (killed) vaccine. It is generally considered safe during pregnancy and can be administered if the benefits outweigh the risks, especially if the woman is at high risk for Hepatitis A infection.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B:  The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, which does not contain live virus. It is safe to use during pregnancy and is recommended for pregnant women who are at risk of Hepatitis B infection.

 

Option C. Rabies:  The Rabies vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. It is considered safe during pregnancy and should be administered if there is a risk of rabies exposure, as the disease itself is fatal if not treated promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the recommended time gap between the application of two live vaccines? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4 weeks

 

  • According to the guidelines of the World Health Organization (WHO), there should be a minimum interval of 4 weeks (28 days) between the administration of two live vaccines.
  • This is to ensure that the immune system has enough time to respond to each vaccine and generate an adequate immune response without interference from the other vaccine.
  • Two live vaccines otherwise can be given together on the same day

 

Educational Objective:

 

General rules for multiple vaccine administration: –

 

  • 2 live vaccines can be given together
  • Live and killed vaccines can be given together
  • Cholera vaccine and Yellow fever vaccine cannot be given together
  • OPV is a live vaccine where single dose is not sufficient for immunization
  • 2 live vaccines can be administered simultaneously at different sites (or at an interval of 4 weeks)

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of variation

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is used to compare the relative variability of different datasets. It is a standardized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution. The CV is particularly useful because it expresses the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, making it possible to compare the degree of variation from one dataset to another, regardless of the unit of measurement or magnitude of the mean.

 

  • Co-efficient of Variation [COV] = SD/Mean x 100
  • It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance measures the spread of a set of numbers. It is the average of the squared differences from the mean. While it indicates variability, it does not provide a standardized measure for comparison between different datasets.

 

Option C. Standard Error of Mean (SEM): The SEM measures how much the sample mean of the data is likely to vary from the true population mean. It is used to understand the accuracy of the sample mean but is not used for comparing variability between datasets.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation (SD): Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. While it indicates the spread of data points, it does not standardize this measure in relation to the mean, which is necessary for comparing different datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

choices.text: MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your hospital emergency with pregnancy 22 weeks, which was a result of rape. Correct statement regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. For gestation periods from 0 to 20 weeks, it is considered low risk and only one doctor’s opinion is required.

 

However, for gestation periods from 20 to 24 weeks, it is categorized as high risk, and the approval of two doctors is required. This high-risk category includes specific situations such as rape, incest, disability, and when the woman is a minor. Since the woman in the question is 22 weeks pregnant due to rape, MTP is permissible under these regulations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG: This is incorrect because MTP after 24 weeks is not routinely allowed. It requires a medical board's approval and is only permitted in exceptional cases involving severe fetal anomalies or conditions that endanger the mother’s life.

 

Option C. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother: This statement is incorrect. For 20-24 weeks POG, MTP is permitted not only for life-threatening conditions but also for cases involving rape, incest, disability, and minors.

 

Option D. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only: This is incorrect because two doctors' opinions are required for high-risk cases between 20-24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy is considered high risk and requires two doctors' opinions, especially in cases of rape, incest, disability, or if the woman is a minor.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has a greyish white membrane over tonsils and presented with bull-neck appearance. She has a 2-year-old brother who is fully immunized for his age. What should be given to the brother? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Nothing should be given

 

The 5-year-old girl shows clinical signs of diphtheria, characterized by a greyish white membrane over the tonsils and bull-neck appearance. The question asks about the appropriate management for her fully immunized 2-year-old brother, who is a close contact.

 

 

For contacts of a diphtheria case:

 

  • If the contact (in this case, the brother) has received primary immunization or a booster within the last 2 years, no additional intervention is needed.
  • If the immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, then a booster dose is required to maintain protection.
  • If the contact is completely unimmunized – Prophylactic t/t with Penicillin or Erythromycin along with 1000-2000 units Diphtheria antitoxin, and start immunization of contact

 

Medical surveillance needs to be done daily and

 

Bacteriological surveillance – swabs on weekly basis 

 

Since the brother is fully immunized for his age, and presumably within the past 2 years, no additional treatment is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillin:  This is used as prophylactic treatment for contacts who are completely unimmunized. It is not indicated for those who are fully vaccinated.

 

Option C.  Diphtheria antitoxin: This is administered to unimmunized contacts for immediate passive immunity, especially when there is a high risk of exposure, but it is not required for fully immunized individuals.

 

Option D.  1 dose of DPT booster:  This is given if the last dose of primary immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, but not needed if within the last 2 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In managing contacts of diphtheria, no additional doses are required if the contact has received primary immunization or booster within the last 2 years.

choices.text: Transition from infectious pandemic diseases to man-made diseases
Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels
Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate
Transition from unfavorable sex ratio to favorable sex ratio

questions.text: What is demographic transition as a country passes through the demographic cycle? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate

 

 

The demographic transition refers to the shift in a country’s population characteristics as it moves through different stages of the demographic cycle. The cycle typically includes five stages, starting with high birth and death rates (Stage 1), followed by declining death rates (Stage 2), declining birth rates (Stage 3), and eventually both low birth and death rates (Stage 4). This process reflects changes in a society’s economic and social conditions, such as improvements in healthcare, education, and overall living standards. The transition leads to slower population growth and ultimately stabilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition from infectious pandemic diseases to man-made diseases: This option describes the epidemiological transition, which refers to the shift in the types of prevalent diseases from infectious to chronic, non-communicable diseases as a society develops.

 

Option B. Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels: This option reflects educational and social changes within a population but does not specifically describe demographic transition.

 

Option D. Transition from unfavorable sex ratio to favorable sex ratio: This option describes changes in gender ratios, often due to social or policy influences, but it is not directly related to demographic transition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demographic transition is characterized by the shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country progresses through the stages of the demographic cycle.

In Triage, these patients are given different color coding as mentioned below –

In disaster triage, moribund patients receive the lowest priority, allowing medical resources to be focused on patients with a higher chance of survival.

questions.text: A lot of patients presented to PHC OPD with edema, ocular problems, cardiac failure. Several deaths were reported too. There was a common history of buying oil from a local grocery store. Drug inspector will use the following test to detect adulteration. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paper chromatography test

 

The condition described in the question is epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil. The toxic component of Argemone oil is Sanguinarine, a potent toxin that inhibits the oxidation of pyruvic acid, leading to symptoms such as bilateral non-inflammatory edema, glaucoma, congestive heart failure, and even death.

 

Paper chromatography test is the most sensitive method to detect Argemone oil adulteration in mustard oil, even at extremely low concentrations (0.0001%). This test identifies the presence of Sanguinarine, thus confirming the contamination of the mustard oil with Argemone oil.

 

Other test is - Nitric acid test shows an orange-brown discoloration if Argemone oil is present, requiring a concentration of 0.25% for a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrate test: This option is incorrect. The nitrate test is commonly employed to detect nitrates in water, food, or soil.

 

Option B. Phosphatase test:  This option is incorrect. The phosphatase test is used primarily to determine the pasteurization status of milk, not for detecting oil adulteration.

 

Option D. Sulphuric acid test: This option is incorrect. While sulphuric acid can be used in various tests, it is not the specific test for detecting Argemone oil adulteration in mustard oil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil, and the most sensitive test for detecting this adulteration is the paper chromatography test.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a means of directly transmitting communicable diseases? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Droplet nuclei

 

  • Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.
  • Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.
  • These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Direct Transmission Methods:

 

Option A. Vertical transmission: This occurs when infections are passed from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding. Examples include HIV and congenital syphilis.

 

Option B. Contact with soil (B): Direct contact with contaminated soil can lead to infections. Soil-transmitted helminths and diseases like tetanus are examples.

 

Option D. Droplet transmission: This involves large respiratory droplets (typically greater than 5 microns) that are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. These droplets can travel short distances and infect individuals through mucosal surfaces (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth). Examples include the common cold, influenza, and COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Droplet nuclei represent an indirect transmission method, as they can remain airborne for long periods and travel over distances, whereas vertical transmission, contact with soil, and droplet transmission are forms of direct transmission of communicable diseases.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the spread of a new viral illness. He wants to determine the probability that a susceptible person will contract the disease after close contact with an infected person. Which measure best describes this probability? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secondary attack rate

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR) measures the probability that a susceptible individual will contract the disease after coming into close contact with an infected individual. It is a useful measure for gauging the infectious potential of an agent within a population.

 

Infectivity is known by calculating the secondary attack rates.


SAR = (Total no. of secondary cases * 100) / (Total susceptible population-primary cases)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial interval is the average time difference between the primary and secondary case, which is similar to the median incubation period

 

Option C. Incubation period: Entry of organism in the human body till the first sign / symptom is produced.

 

Option D. The Case fatality rate = (Number of deaths due to a disease / number of cases of that particular disease) * 100

 

Case fatality rate typically is used as a measure of disease severity and is often used for prognosis. Always expressed in %. CFR of Rabies is 100%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR) is a critical measure for assessing the infectious potential of a disease, indicating the likelihood that a disease will spread among susceptible individuals after exposure to an infected person.

questions.text: The given image is the logo for which of the following health programs? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) National Leprosy Eradication Program


The logo shown is for the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP). The design of the logo holds significant meaning:

 

  • Sun: The sun in the center of the hand symbolizes hope and optimism, reflecting the positive outcomes of leprosy treatment.
  • Lotus Flower: This represents purity and beauty, indicating that there should be no stigma attached to those affected by leprosy.
  • Cured Thumb: The image of the healed thumb symbolizes that leprosy is a 100% curable disease. The thumb indicates that the affected person has been cured and is now a fully integrated member of society.
  • House-Shaped Hand: The hand shaped like a house emphasizes that the cured individual is an integral part of their family and community.

 

These elements collectively reinforce the message of hope, inclusion, and the need to remove stigma associated with leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated Disease Surveillance Program (logo):

 

 

Option B.  National TB Elimination Program (logo):

 

 

Option D.  National Health Mission (logo):

 

 

Educational Objective:


The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live birts) by the year 2030? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) <70

 

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: A female presented to the OPD within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse. Which contraception is advised? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IUCD

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a female presenting within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse, the most effective emergency contraceptive (interceptive) method advised is the intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).

 

The IUCD is the recommended method of choice for emergency contraception with the highest efficacy and least failure rate when used within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Misoprostol: This option is incorrect because misoprostol is not an emergency contraceptive method.

 

Option C. LNG: Levonorgestrel (LNG) is a widely accepted method of emergency contraception and is recommended as a first-line option. However, its effectiveness is optimal only within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, with significantly reduced efficacy beyond this timeframe. And an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) remains the most effective alternative, providing protection for up to 5 days post-intercourse.

 

Option D. OCP: This option is incorrect. While combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are an option, they are not the recommended method of choice when the female presents within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended emergency contraceptive method currently in use are –

 

  • OCPs (Yuzpe and Lancee Method) –  (pills with 30 mcg oestrogen) - 4 pills immediately followed by 4 pills 12 hours later. This method can be used till 72hrs of intercourse.
  • Mini Pills (POP): Progesterone only Pill (POP) 0.75 mg – Pill has to be ‘used within 72 hours of intercourse (LNG oral tablet (0.75 mg): 1st tablet within 72 hours of intercourse and 2nd tablet after 12 hours of first dose)
  • IUCD (most effective; highest efficacy & least failure) – can be used till 5 days
  • RU486 (mifepristone) – within 72 hours
  • High dose of estrogen – to be continuously used for 5 days

choices.text: Screening and treatment for STI and RTI

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically recognized as a primary component of the RCH program? (FMGE JAN 2023)

While education and empowerment of women are crucial for overall health improvement, they are not specifically listed as a primary component of the RCH program.

 

Other Options:

 

The Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) program focuses on specific health services to improve the health of mothers and children. The primary components of the RCH program include:

 

Option B. Children and newborn care: Services aimed at ensuring the health and well-being of children and newborns.

 

Option C. Screening and treatment for STI and RTI: Control and prevention of reproductive tract infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted infections (STI).

 

Option D. Safe motherhood: Initiatives to ensure the health and safety of mothers during pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Component of RCH program -

questions.solution:
Ans. C. Td booster dose

 

As per National Immunization Schedule, the recommendations for pregnant woman are as follows: -

Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1

 

Td-Booster dose: if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

For pregnant women who received the complete Td vaccination course during their last pregnancy within the last three years, a Td booster dose is recommended.

choices.text: Crude birth rate – Crude death rate
Crude birth rate + Crude death rate
Crude birth rate / Crude death rate
Crude birth rate × Crude death rate

questions.text: What is Demographic gap? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Crude birth rate – Crude death rate

 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate. It essentially measures the net increase in the population, referred to as the growth rate.

 

In demographic terms:

 

  • A positive demographic gap indicates that the birth rate is higher than the death rate, leading to population growth.
  • A negative demographic gap indicates a declining population when the death rate exceeds the birth rate.

 

The demographic gap is minimal during the early and late stages of the demographic transition model (Stages 1 and 4), where birth and death rates are balanced or declining. It peaks during Stage 2 when the birth rate remains high but the death rate drops significantly. In Stage 3, the gap starts to contract as birth rates begin to fall, and in Stage 5, it can become negative as populations age and birth rates fall below death rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The demographic gap is defined as the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate, representing the population growth rate

questions.text: In a screening examination conducted on a population of 1000 individuals for diabetes mellitus (DM), 90 individuals tested positive. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was performed, identifying 100 positive cases. What is the calculated sensitivity? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 90/100

 

In given question, the following data are provided:

 

Total population = 1000

 

Total diseased people = 100 (identified by gold standard test)

 

Total number of diabetics identified initially = 90, thus

 

total positive identified by screening test =90

 

 

Therefore:

 

Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN) =90/ (90+10) = 90/100 = 90%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensitivity is the proportion of true positive cases correctly identified by a screening test out of all actual positive cases identified by the gold standard test.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Common intermittent source epidemic

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows cases occurring at irregular intervals with gaps between them, indicating that people are exposed intermittently to the source of infection. This pattern is characteristic of a common intermittent source epidemic, where exposures occur sporadically, leading to multiple peaks over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic: Characterized by a sudden rise and fall in the number of cases within a single incubation period, showing a single peak.

 

 

Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic: Shows multiple peaks due to repeated exposures, but the rise and fall are not as sudden and are marked by secondary waves.

 

 

Options C. Propagated epidemic: Involves person-to-person transmission, typically showing a slow rise, a plateau, and a slow fall in the number of cases over time.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A common intermittent source epidemic is marked by cases appearing at irregular intervals, reflecting intermittent exposures to the source of infection.

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cardiovascular diseases 

 

Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

 

The WHO MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) Project was designed to measure trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease mortality and coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease morbidity, and to assess the extent to which these trends are related to changes in known risk factors in different populations in 27 countries (10 years’ period)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scope of Project MONICA is focused on cardiovascular diseases, specifically monitoring trends in coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease and examining the impact of various risk factors on these conditions.

questions.text: Not included in STEPS approach for Non-communicable diseases is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood grouping

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO STEPS approach for non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance involves three steps: behavioral measurements, physical measurements, and biochemical measurements. These steps focus on key indicators related to NCDs and stroke surveillance.

 

The specific indicators include:

 

  • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus.
  • Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate.
  • Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.

 

Blood grouping is not a part of the STEPS approach as it does not relate to the risk factors or measurements for NCDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood sugar: Included as a core biochemical measurement (blood glucose).

 

Option B. Blood pressure: Included as a core physical measurement.

 

Option D. Blood lipids: Included as a core biochemical measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO STEPS approach for NCD risk factor surveillance includes behavioral, physical, and biochemical measurements, but blood grouping is not included in these indicators.

questions.text: Which of the following is not constrained by time? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goal

 

Explanation:

 

A goal is the ultimate desired state that a health program aims to achieve. It is not constrained by time, meaning that a goal does not have a specific timeline associated with it. Additionally, a goal is not necessarily attainable, as it represents the ultimate desired outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Objective:  An objective is a specific, planned activity in a health program. Objectives are designed to help achieve the goal and are usually associated with a timeline.

 

Option B. Target:  A target is the degree of achievement of objectives and is always associated with a timeline.

 

Option D. Principle:  The principles are generally guidelines or fundamental truths and do not specify timelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of health programs, a goal is the ultimate desired state and is not constrained by time or resources. It represents an "all or none" phenomenon and may not always be attainable.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy at 22 weeks of gestation for contraceptive failure after 21 weeks requires approval from:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 doctors

 

Explanation:

 

Now, MTP is permitted till 24 weeks of gestation. It is divided into two categories: low-risk MTP and high-risk MTP.

 

Low-risk MTP: performed up to 20 weeks of gestation, requires the approval of only one doctor.

 

High-risk MTP: includes cases where the gestational age is between 20 weeks to 24 weeks, the approval of two doctors is required.

 

The specifies that the MTP is being considered at 22 weeks of gestation, which falls under the high-risk category. Therefore, the approval of two doctors is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 doctor: This option is incorrect because gestational ages above 20 weeks and up to 24 weeks, the approval of two doctors is required.

 

Option C. Court: This option is incorrect because court approval is not required for MTP up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Option D. Medical board: This option is incorrect because a medical board's approval is only required for cases involving severe fetal malformations after 24 weeks of gestation, not for the scenario described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation, which is considered a high-risk category, the approval of two doctors is required.

questions.text: What method is most effective for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a given area over time? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Line graph

 

Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area over time (TREND of any event).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histogram: Is graphical presentation for ‘continuous quantitative data’

 

  • Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

 

Option C. Ogive:  Is graph of cumulative relative frequency distribution

 

 

Option D. Stem and leaf plot:  Represents quantitative data in graphical format which helps us visualize the shape of distribution. We are able to represent frequencies for different classes of values.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Line graphs are the most effective method for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence over time, making them ideal for identifying and analyzing trends in epidemiological data.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male travels frequently and has food during his travels. He presents to PHC OPD with abdominal pain, fever for 4 days. He has bradycardia too. Test for confirmation of diagnosis: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood culture

 

The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of enteric fever (typhoid), characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. The appropriate diagnostic test depends on the stage of the illness:

 

Blood culture is the test of choice from the first week of illness onwards. It remains the most reliable test in the initial stages (within the first week of symptoms) to confirm typhoid fever. This test directly detects the presence of Salmonella bacteria in the blood, making it the most accurate diagnostic method during early illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella and is typically used from the second week of illness onwards. It is not the preferred test during the first week as antibodies may not yet be present in detectable quantities.

 

Option C. Stool culture: This is used from the third week of illness onwards and detects Salmonella in the gastrointestinal tract. It is not suitable for early diagnosis as it becomes positive later in the disease course.

 

Option D. Urine culture: This is used from the fourth week of illness onwards. It detects Salmonella excreted in the urine, but like stool culture, it is useful later in the course of the disease and not for initial diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For typhoid fever diagnosis in the first week of illness, blood culture is the most appropriate and reliable test.

 

Mnemonic – BASU

 

Blood culture – 1st week onwards

Antibody test (Widal) – 2nd week onwards

Stool culture – 3rd week onwards

Urine culture – 4th week onwards

questions.text: Rukmani is attending a Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme. How frequently is it conducted? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Every month

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee organizes a Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day once every month.

 

Rukmani is attending a "Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme," which is likely referring to the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day organized by the committee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Programme, which Rukmani is attending, is conducted once every month by the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee.

questions.text: True regarding Oral Cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Bivalent with 2 doses

 

The oral cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is a bivalent vaccine designed to protect against serotypes O1 and O139 of the cholera bacteria. It is administered as 2 liquid doses for individuals aged 1 year and older, with a booster dose recommended every 2 years. The vaccine does not contain subunit B antitoxin; hence it does not require a buffer during administration.

 

Educational Objective:


CHOLERA ORAL VACCINES:

 

  •  Dukoral (WC-rBS): Monovalent, V cholera O1 plus Recombinant Toxin B subunit.
    • 2 doses (if age ≥6 years) and booster once/ 2 years
    • 3 doses (if age b/w 2-5 years) and booster dose once per 6 months.
  •  Sanchol and mORCVAX: Bivalent, Serogroups O1 & O139, No toxin B subunit, No buffer required. 2 liquid doses after the age of 1 year and booster after 2 years.
  • Euvichol: it is just like Sanchol. Bivalent with 2 doses.

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Component bar graph

 

  • The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.
  • A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.
  • In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Histogram is used for continuous quantitative data presentation.

 

 

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are

 

separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

 

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

 

Option B. Line Diagram: Is a better chart Used in depiction of TREND. There is no closed loop and no histogram in the background.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Bar Graphs: Multiple bar graphs show two or more sets of data simultaneously with separate bars for each category side by side. This is different from a component bar graph, where each bar is divided into segments representing different components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

questions.text:
PQLI indicators include: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Literacy rate
  2. Infant mortality rate
  3. Life expectancy at birth
  4. Income per capita
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Only two of these

 

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life in different countries. It focuses on three main indicators: health, education, and living standards. Specifically, these indicators include:

 

1. Literacy Rate (Education): This measures the education level within a population and is included in the PQLI.

 

2. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Living Standards): This measures the number of infants who die before reaching one year of age, reflecting living conditions and healthcare quality. It is included in the PQLI.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Life Expectancy at Birth: This is not included in the PQLI; instead, PQLI considers life expectancy at age one.

 

4. Income per Capita: This is not part of the PQLI; income measurements are used in the Human Development Index (HDI) but not in PQLI.

 

Thus, only the literacy rate and infant mortality rate are included in the PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.

 

Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to OPD with fever and neurological complications. He was having respiratory difficulty during the examination. Identify the disease transmitted through the life cycle shown in the image. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus disease


The life cycle shown in the image involves Pteropus bats, also known as fruit bats or flying foxes, which are natural reservoirs for the Nipah virus. The transmission cycle depicted shows bats contaminating fruits or other food sources with their secretions, which can then be consumed by humans or other animals like pigs, leading to the spread of the virus. Nipah virus is known for causing severe respiratory illness and neurological symptoms, with a high fatality rate of around 50%. There is no vaccine for Nipah virus, and treatment is primarily supportive and symptomatic.

 

Incubation period – 4-14 days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus disease: Zika virus is primarily transmitted through mosquito bites and does not involve bats or fruit contamination in its transmission cycle. It primarily causes mild symptoms and is not associated with the severe respiratory and neurological symptoms described here.

 

Option B. Dengue disease: Dengue is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and does not involve bats or fruit contamination. It typically presents with fever, headache, and joint pain rather than severe neurological symptoms or respiratory difficulty.

 

Option C. Yellow fever disease: Yellow fever is also transmitted through mosquito bites, mainly the Aedes and Haemagogus species, and does not involve bats. It causes fever, jaundice, and bleeding but does not match the transmission cycle or clinical presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:


Nipah virus is transmitted through contact with Pteropus bats, contaminated food, or animals that have been exposed to the virus. It causes severe respiratory and neurological symptoms with a high fatality rate and no available vaccine.

questions.text: What is the reservoir of leishmaniasis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Man

 

Explanation:

 

The reservoir of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kalazar or Indian kala-azar, is humans.

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar) is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani.
  • The vector responsible for transmitting the disease is the sandfly (Phlebotomus species).

 

 

  • The reservoir host of the disease is humans (man).

 

Other 3 options are incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

For visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar or Indian kala-azar), the reservoir host is humans.

questions.text: What is the term for the probability of infection occurring in susceptible individuals after they come into contact with an infectious person during the incubation period? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Secondary attack rate

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR): Is no. of exposed persons developing the disease within range of incubation period (IP), following exposure to the primary case

 

It is calculated by the following formula:

 

 

Primary case is excluded from both numerator & denominator

 

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease / Infectivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Case fatality rate: This rate measures the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a particular disease who die from that disease within a specific period. It is a measure of the severity of the disease.

 

Option C. Primary attack rate: This rate refers to the proportion of the population that becomes ill after being exposed to an infectious agent for the first time. It does not specifically account for subsequent spread among contacts.

 

Option D. Tertiary attack rate: This term is not commonly used in epidemiology. It would imply further transmission beyond secondary contacts, but this is not a standard measure

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary attack rate is a crucial epidemiological measure for understanding the spread of infectious diseases among contacts of an initial case. It helps determine the infectivity and potential for outbreaks within a population.

questions.text: Under the Urban health care system of India, the following health centre is not included: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) District hospital

 

Explanation:

 

District hospitals, however, are not a part of the urban healthcare system's primary or secondary level facilities, hence they are not included.

 

Urban Health care system of India

 

  • There is a provision for creating urban health and wellness centres, which cater to a population of 15,000 to 20,000.
  • These centres are akin to primary health centres (PHCs) in rural areas. Additionally, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), previously known as Urban Health Centres, serve a population of 50,000.
  • Urban polyclinics are created for a population of 2.5 to 3 lakh.
  • At the secondary level, Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC) are established for a population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

District hospitals are not included in the urban healthcare system of India; instead, urban health facilities include Urban Health and Wellness Centres, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), Urban Polyclinics, and Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC).

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hypochlorous acid

 

The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness. It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochlorite Ion (OCl⁻): While it does have disinfectant properties, it is much less effective compared to hypochlorous acid.

 

Option B. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl): This is a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and water but does not contribute significantly to the disinfectant quality.

 

Option D. Chloride Ion (Cl⁻): This is also a byproduct of the disinfection process and does not play a direct role in the disinfectant action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleaching powder (CaOCl2)

 

  • 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl → HCI + HOCI HOCI → H + OCI
